articles.headline: Syrian Crematory Is Hiding Mass Killings of Prisoners, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: The State Department released satellite images showing a building thought to be a crematory, which would enable bodies to be disposed of without leaving evidence behind.
articles.abstract: The State Department released satellite images showing a building thought to be a crematory, which would enable bodies to be disposed of without leaving evidence behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States accused the Syrian government on Monday of using a crematory to hide mass murders at a prison where thousands are believed to have been summarily executed in the nation’s civil war.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris, Anne Barnard and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: A Whistle-Blower Tells of Health Insurers Bilking Medicare
articles.snippet: A former executive at UnitedHealth says he was paid bonuses to make patients look sicker than they were, which led to bigger reimbursements.
articles.abstract: A former executive at UnitedHealth says he was paid bonuses to make patients look sicker than they were, which led to bigger reimbursements.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Medicare was facing an impossible $13 trillion funding gap, Congress opted for a bold fix: It handed over part of the program to insurance companies, expecting them to provide better care at a lower cost. The new program was named Medicare Advantage.

articles.headline: Trump Revealed Highly Classified Intelligence to Russia, in Break With Ally, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The intelligence disclosed was about an Islamic State plot, according to officials.
articles.abstract: The intelligence disclosed was about an Islamic State plot, according to officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump boasted about highly classified intelligence in a meeting with the Russian foreign minister and ambassador last week, providing details that could expose the source of the information and the manner in which it was collected, a current and a former American government official said Monday.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: 20 Years On, Amazon and Jeff Bezos Prove Naysayers Wrong
articles.snippet: Let us now praise a famous Master of the Internet, who has changed the way we live — and isn’t done yet.
articles.abstract: Let us now praise a famous Master of the Internet, who has changed the way we live — and isn’t done yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago this week, Amazon.com went public.

articles.headline: In Computer Attacks, Clues Point to Frequent Culprit: North Korea
articles.snippet: Indicators are far from conclusive, but intelligence officials and private security experts say that North Korean-linked hackers are likely suspects in global ransomware attacks.
articles.abstract: Indicators are far from conclusive, but intelligence officials and private security experts say that North Korean-linked hackers are likely suspects in global ransomware attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intelligence officials and private security experts say that new digital clues point to North Korean-linked hackers as likely suspects in the sweeping ransomware attacks that have crippled computer systems around the world.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Managers Don’t Always Beat the Market, but They Still Make Billions
articles.snippet: The 25 best-paid managers earned a collective $11 billion in 2016. But some big names, like William A. Ackman and John A. Paulson, did not make the cut.
articles.abstract: The 25 best-paid managers earned a collective $11 billion in 2016. But some big names, like William A. Ackman and John A. Paulson, did not make the cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good performance, mediocre results or even downright ugly returns. When it comes to hedge funds, it scarcely matters. Even as some investors begin to sour on these high-priced stock pickers, the top fund managers still haul in enormous paychecks.

articles.headline: Democrats Escalate Calls for Trump Inquiry, With Republicans More Reserved
articles.snippet: Some lawmakers called for James B. Comey to appear before Congress after reports that President Trump had asked him to drop an investigation into Michael T. Flynn.
articles.abstract: Some lawmakers called for James B. Comey to appear before Congress after reports that President Trump had asked him to drop an investigation into Michael T. Flynn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress from both parties escalated calls on Tuesday for former F.B.I. director James B. Comey to appear before them after reports that President Trump had asked him to drop an investigation into Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Emmarie Huetteman
